Adam_Harvey:
{{short description|Australian country music singer (born 1974)}} {{for-multi|the English actor|Adam Paul Harvey|the American artist|Adam Harvey (artist)}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist | image = Adam Harvey.jpg | name = Adam Harvey | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1974|12|21}} | birth_place = [[Geelong]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia | death_date = | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | occupation = Singer, songwriter | years_active = 1984–present | label = Open Road, Universal, [[ABC Music]], [[Sony Music]] | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|http://adamharvey.com.au}} }} '''Adam Harvey''' (born 21 December 1974) is an Australian [[country music]] singer. Harvey has sold over half a million records, has been nominated five times for an [[ARIA Music Awards|ARIA Music Award]] and has won nine [[Country Music Awards of Australia|golden guitars at the Country Music Awards of Australia]].{{cite web|url=http://cruisincountry.com.au/2019/performers/adam-harvey/|title=Adam Harvey|publisher=Cruis' Country|access-date=4 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180804110221/http://cruisincountry.com.au/2019/performers/adam-harvey/|archive-date=4 August 2018|url-status=dead}} ==Biography== Harvey got his start musically learning country classics on the guitar as a small boy. His first gig came at the age of ten, and by his school years he was performing rock covers at a club when he was discovered and went off on tour as support for [[Tania Kernaghan]].{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p698129|pure_url=yes}}|title=Adam harvey|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|last=True|first=Chris|access-date=29 January 2010}} In 1998 Harvey won his first [[Country Music Awards of Australia|Country Music (CMAA) Award]] for 'Vocal Collaboration of the Year' with Tanya Self for "Drive Away".{{cite web|url=http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1134 |title=Country Music Awards of Australia 1990–1999 |publisher=[[Country Music Association of Australia|CMAA]] |access-date=29 January 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091017180321/http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1134 |archive-date=17 October 2009 }} In 2001 he won another CMAA Award for 'Vocal Collaboration of the Year' this time with [[Beccy Cole]], Darren Coggan and [[Felicity Urquhart|Felicity]], for "Do I Ever Cross Your Mind".{{cite web|url=http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1135 |title=Country Music Awards of Australia 2000–2008 |publisher=[[Country Music Association of Australia|CMAA]] |access-date=29 January 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091017175108/http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1135 |archive-date=17 October 2009 }} In 2002, Harvey won two CMAA Awards; 'Album of the Year' and 'Male Vocalist of the Year' for ''Workin' Overtime''. ''Workin' Overtime'' was nominated for [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album]] at the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2002|2002 ARIA Awards]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ariaawards.com.au/history-by-artist.php?letter=A&artist=Adam%20Harvey |title=ARIA Award History – Adam Harvey |publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association]] |access-date=29 January 2010 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 2004, Harvey won a second CMAA Award for 'Male Vocalist of the Year' that year. In 2005 he received his third [[ARIA Music Awards of 2005|ARIA award]] nomination for Best Country Album ''Can't Settle for Less''. In 2008, he won Album of the Year ''I'm Doin' Alright''. In 2009, he sang the [[Australian national anthem]] before the Australia vs New Zealand [[rugby league]] test match.{{citation needed|date=December 2021}} Harvey has been nominated for a CMAA Award in 2010 for Collaboration of the Year with [[John Williamson (singer)|John Williamson]] for "King of the Road".{{cite web|url=http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1226 |title=Finalists – 38th CMAA Country Music Awards of Australia |publisher=[[Country Music Association of Australia|CMAA]] |access-date=27 January 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100301214250/http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1226 |archive-date=1 March 2010 |url-status=dead |df=dmy }} {{externalvideo | float = right | width = 250px | video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J45LnaI3F9I Official Music Video ''Stuck in the Middle''] | }} In 2013, Harvey collaborated with [[Troy Cassar-Daley]] to record ''[[The Great Country Songbook]]'', which debuted at number 2 on the [[ARIA Charts]]. ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:12em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:17em;"| Details ! colspan="1"| Peak positions ! rowspan="2" style="width:10em;"| [[Music recording sales certification|Certifications]]

Certifications |- ! scope="row"| ''Best So Far'' | * Release date: 2010 * Label: [[Sony Music Australia]] * Formats: DVD | align="left"| * ARIA: Gold {{Cite certification |region=Australia |type=video |certyear=2014 |accessdate=24 July 2020}} |- |} ==Awards and nominations== ===ARIA Awards=== Harvey had been nominated for 5 awards at the [[ARIA Music Awards]]{{cite web|url=https://www.ariaawards.com.au/search?term=Adam%20Harvey|title=ARIA Award Search Harvey|access-date=14 September 2018}} {{awards table}} |- | [[ARIA Music Awards of 2002|2002]] || ''Workin' Overtime'' || [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]] || {{nominated}} |- | [[ARIA Music Awards of 2003|2003]] || ''Cowboy Dreams'' || Best Country Album || {{nominated}} |- | [[ARIA Music Awards of 2005|2005]] || ''Can't Settle for Less'' || Best Country Album || {{nominated}} |- | [[ARIA Music Awards of 2010|2010]] || ''Both Sides Now'' || Best Country Album || {{nominated}} |- | [[ARIA Music Awards of 2013|2013]] || ''[[The Great Country Songbook]]'' (with [[Troy Cassar-Daley]]) || Best Country Album || {{nominated}} |- {{end}} ===CMA Awards=== The [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] is an annual awards night held in January during the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]], celebrating recording excellence in the [[Australian country music]] industry.
